content: The annual Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies appropriations bill provides funding for Department of the Interior agencies, the Forest Service, the Indian Health Service, the EPA, arts and cultural agencies, and other entities. The appropriations laws for Interior and Related Agencies previously funded Department of Energy programs, Naval Petroleum Reserves, and the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. These DOE programs were transferred to energy and water subcommittees, while EPA and smaller entities were moved to Interior subcommittees for funding in annual bills. The appropriations bill underwent changes due to the abolition of certain subcommittees, resulting in a reorganization of funding for agencies like the EPA. The report is structured into sections focusing on Interior agencies, EPA, other agencies, programs, and cross-cutting topics. Major agencies and issues receiving funding in the appropriations bill are discussed, including key funding details. The appropriations bill discusses key funding changes for various agencies and policy issues of interest to Congress. It is a complex process with numerous funding and programmatic changes not fully summarized in the report. For more information on specific programs funded in the bill, contact the listed policy staff members. The term appropriations in the report refers to total available funds, including regular annual allocations. The term appropriations in the report represents total available funds, including regular annual and supplemental appropriations, as well as rescissions, transfers, and deferrals. The House Committee on Appropriations is the primary source of funding figures used, with other sources including the Senate Committee on Appropriations, agency budget justifications, and the Congressional Record. Funding figures in tables may not match precise totals due to rounding. Appropriations for accounts within annual Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies appropriations laws are available for varying periods depending on program needs. The Interior appropriations laws provide one-year appropriations for various accounts, with some accounts having appropriations for longer periods, including multiple fiscal years. Some accounts in the Interior appropriations laws have appropriations for multiple fiscal years, allowing for carryover of funds from one year to the next without a deadline for obligation. These "no-year appropriations" remain available until expended. The appropriation for the Fish and Wildlife Service in P.L. 112-74 provides an example of no-year appropriations, allowing funds to remain available until expended. Congress enacted the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2012, with $29.23 billion for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies in FY2012, including a 0.16% across-the-board reduction. This marked a decrease from the FY2011 level and the President's request for FY2012. The FY2012 appropriations law included a $29.61 billion level, a $2.11 billion decrease from the President's request. The law called for rescissions to be calculated by OMB, with few increases over FY2011 for major agencies funded by the bill. Notable increases included $244.2 million for the Indian Health Service and $51.9 million for the Smithsonian Institution. The FY2012 law reduced funding for various agencies compared to FY2011 levels. Reductions included $219.1 million (3%) for the Environmental Protection Agency, $83.4 million (2%) for the Forest Service, $27.3 million (1%) for the National Park Service, and $25.3 million (2%) for the Fish and Wildlife Service. The law addressed diverse issues affecting multiple agencies and emphasized following guidance and reporting requirements outlined in the House Appropriations Committee report. The FY2012 law included a provision requiring DOI agencies, EPA, FS, and IHS to report quarterly to the House and Senate Appropriations Committees on balances of appropriations, specifying uncommitted, committed, and unobligated funds. The House Appropriations Committee sought information on the source year of remaining funds to assess if appropriations exceeded needs or if administrative inefficiencies hindered fund expenditure. The FY2012 law included a provision to extend the Service First initiative, aiming to improve services and reduce costs by co-locating field offices of DOI agencies and the FS. The House Appropriations Committee requested a report on the initiative's costs, successes, and recommendations for improvement. Additionally, agencies were directed to report on actions taken to address management weaknesses and implement reforms identified by Inspectors General and the Government Accountability Office, as well as the costs of litigation related to agency actions. The House Appropriations Committee requested information on payments of attorney fees and expenses under the Equal Access to Justice Act, citing rising litigation costs and agencies spending over half of their funds on litigation. The report also included recommendations for agencies with unauthorized or expired authorizations, recommending a total appropriation of $7.25 billion for these agencies. The committee recommended a $7.25 billion appropriation for agencies with unauthorized or expired authorizations, emphasizing the need for authorizing committees to secure authorizations to avoid continual funding. Authorizing legislation establishes, continues, or modifies agencies or programs, outlining their duties, functions, and organizational structure, as well as authorizing appropriations. The House Appropriations Committee recommended downsizing and restructuring agencies to achieve economies of scale, with a focus on consolidating regional offices. DOI, EPA, FS, and IHS were directed to submit a joint proposal on office consolidation and provide staffing and funding lists in their annual budget requests. No regular FY2012 appropriations bill for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies was enacted before October 1, 2011, leading to funding through continuing resolutions until the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2012 was passed. The FY2012 funding for agencies and activities was provided through continuing appropriations laws, aiming to reduce discretionary spending to the government-wide total allowed under the Budget Control Act of 2011. A draft bill for FY2012 was released by the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies, but no regular appropriations bill was enacted before October 1, 2011. The House considered H.R. 2584 for FY2012 appropriations for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies, but no resolution was reached. The House Appropriations Committee proposed a bill with $27.52 billion in appropriations for FY2012, a 7% reduction from FY2011. The bill included a notable increase of $392.4 million (10%) for the Indian Health Service, but recommended decreases for other agencies such as the Environmental Protection Agency, Fish and Wildlife Service, Forest Service, and National Park. The President's proposed budget for FY2012 included significant increases for various agencies, such as $554.6 million (14%) for the Indian Health Service, $290.9 million (3%) for the Environmental Protection Agency, and $280.4 million (11%) for the National Park Service. These proposed increases contrasted with the House Appropriations Committee's bill, which recommended reduced appropriations for several agencies. For FY2012, Congress debated funding and policy issues including regulatory actions, energy development, wildland fire fighting, Indian trust fund management, climate change, DOI science programs, endangered species, and agency reorganizations. Decreases in funding were proposed for various agencies, such as $93.4 million (4%) for the Bureau of Indian Affairs, $16.9 million (5%) for the National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities, and $16.6 million (10%) for the Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement. Other issues included funding levels for Indian Health Service construction and contract health services, wastewater/drinking water needs, and land acquisition. Among the major issues discussed in FY2012 Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies appropriations hearings were Clean Water and Drinking Water State Revolving Funds for wastewater and drinking water infrastructure projects, and Endangered Species Act funding for new species protection and critical habitat designation. The FY2012 Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies appropriations hearings focused on funding for various environmental regulations, including the Endangered Species Act, EPA regulatory actions, Indian Health Service programs, and Land Acquisition for the Land and Water Conservation Fund. In response to the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, Secretary of the Interior Ken Salazar announced the separation of functions within the Minerals Management Service. Three new entities were established - Bureau of Ocean Energy Management (BOEM), Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement (BSEE), and the Office of Natural Resources Revenue (ONRR). The transition to this new framework was completed on October 1, 2011. Each entity has a director under the supervision of an assistant secretary. BOEM manages the development of the nation's offshore resources. The Bureau of Ocean Energy Management (BOEM) manages offshore resource development, while the Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement (BSEE) enforces safety regulations. The Office of Natural Resources Revenue (ONRR) collects and disburses revenues from energy leases. Prior to BOEM and BSEE, the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation, and Enforcement (BOEMRE) handled these activities. In FY2011, disbursements from mineral leases on federal and Indian lands totaled $11.2 billion, fluctuating annually based on oil and gas prices. The Bureau of Indian Affairs provides services to tribes and historically leads federal dealings with them. The act will have a significant impact on tribal courts, law enforcement, and detention centers by allowing extended jail sentences for tribal citizens convicted of crimes. The Tribal Law and Order Act (TLOA) allows tribal courts to give longer jail sentences to tribal citizens convicted of crimes under tribal codes.
